title: Hans Rietz
text:
Hans Rietz (26 April 1914 – 25 May 1996) was an <a href="East%20Germany">East German</a> politician who became a top official in the country's <a href="Democratic%20Farmers%27%20Party%20of%20Germany">Democratic Farmers' Party (" Demokratische Bauernpartei Deutschlands" / DBD)</a>, which was one of five <a href="National%20Front%20%28East%20Germany%29">so-called bloc parties</a> controlled by the <a href="Socialist%20Unity%20Party%20of%20Germany">ruling Socialist Unity Party of Germany ("Sozialistische Einheitspartei Deutschlands" / SED)</a>. For many years Rietz served as a member of the <a href="Volkskammer">National parliament ("Volkskammer")</a> and he was also a long-standing deputy chairman of the <a href="State%20Council%20of%20East%20Germany">State Council</a>.
Life.
Hans Rietz was born to a working-class mother in <a href="K%C3%B6nnern">Könnern</a>, a small manufacturing town between <a href="Magdeburg">Magdeburg</a> and <a href="Halle%20%28Saale%29">Halle</a>. Little is known of his father, but in 1960 it was reported by <a href="Neues%20Deutschland">Neues Deutschland</a>, the mass-circulation newspaper of <a href="Socialist%20Unity%20Party%20of%20Germany">East Germany's ruling SED (party)</a>, that the father of Hans Dietz was a member of the <a href="Spartacus%20League">Spartacus League</a> and later of <a href="Weimar%20Germany">Germany's</a> <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20Germany">Communist Party</a> which grew out of it.
He attended junior and middle school at nearby <a href="Bitterfeld">Bitterfeld</a>, before undertaking an apprenticeship at <a href="Wolfen%2C%20Germany">Wolfen</a> as a machinist between 1928 and 1932. From the start of his apprenticeship Rietz was a member of the <a href="Young%20Communist%20League%20of%20Germany">Young Communists</a> and of the <a href="German%20Metal%20Workers%27%20Union">Metal Workers' Union ("Deutscher Metallarbeiter-Verband" / DMV)</a>. On successful completion of the apprenticeship he remained with <a href="IG%20Farben">IG Farben</a>, working as a machinist at their large <a href="Wolfen%2C%20Germany">Wolfen</a> plant till 1939, apart from a two-year break for mandatory <a href="military%20service">military service</a>. (The term of had been extended from one year to two with effect from 24 August 1936.)
<a href="Invasion%20of%20Poland">War returned</a> in September 1939: Rietz was conscripted initially into the <a href="Reich%20Labour%20Service">National Labour Service ("Reichsarbeitsdienst" / RAD)</a> and later into the <a href="Wehrmacht">army</a>. He was sent to fight on the <a href="Eastern%20Front%20%28World%20War%20II%29">Russian front</a> and had reached the junior-officer rank of <a href="Oberwachtmeister">Oberwachtmeister</a> by the time he was captured by the <a href="Red%20army">Soviets</a>. In the prisoner of war camp he was politically active, undertaking various courses at the camp anti-fascist school. Rietz was returned to Germany in 1949. The central portion of what had previously been Germany was administered after <a href="End%20of%20World%20War%20II%20in%20Europe">1945</a> as the <a href="Soviet%20occupation%20zone">Soviet occupation zone</a> and there is speculation that his return was connected with a willingness to undertake a political role in the zone, which would be relaunched in October 1949 as the <a href="Group%20of%20Soviet%20Forces%20in%20Germany">Soviet sponsored</a> <a href="German%20Democratic%20Republic">German Democratic Republic (East Germany)</a>.
He immediately joined the <a href="Free%20German%20Trade%20Union%20Federation">Free [East] German Trade Union Federation ("Freier Deutsche Gewerkschaftsbund" / FDGB)</a> and the newly launched <a href="Democratic%20Farmers%27%20Party%20of%20Germany">Democratic Farmers' Party ("Demokratische Bauernpartei Deutschlands" / DBD)</a>. Within the DBD he took a position as head of the party's national "Thomas Münzer" party academy at <a href="Borkheide">Borkheide</a> (<a href="Bad%20Belzig">Belzig</a>), and over the next three years successfully built up both the institution and his own credentials with the national leadership. He became a member of the <a href="Democratic%20Farmers%27%20Party%20of%20Germany">DBD</a> executive in 1951 and was thereafter engaged in a succession of leadership functions within the party. Between 1954 and 1982 he was a member of the presidium within the executive, becoming Party Secretary for Organisation in 1963 and serving as a deputy party president between 1963 and 1982. During several years in the mid-1950s and again between 1977 and 1982 he served as chair of the party court, a position he held in succession to . Later he served as chair of the party's veterans' commission.
Following the so-called <a href="1954%20East%20German%20general%20election">General Election of 1954</a> the <a href="Democratic%20Farmers%27%20Party%20of%20Germany">DBD</a> was allocated 52 of the 466 seats in the <a href="Volkskammer">National Parliament ("Volkskammer")</a>, and one of those seats went to Hans Rietz. He would remain of the assembly, even after retiring from his more onerous political functions, till 1986. From 1963 he was a deputy chair of the parliamentary defence committee. He represented the DBD as a member of the parliamentary presidium between 1976 and 1981.
By <a href="Die%20Wende">1990</a> Hans Rietz had retired from active participation in East German politics. In March of that year East Germany held its <a href="1990%20East%20German%20general%20election">first and, as matters turned out, last free and fair general election</a>. The <a href="Democratic%20Farmers%27%20Party%20of%20Germany">DBD</a> achieved slightly above 2% of the national vote, implying a lack of popular support under a democratic system. According to some analyses the DBD's creation, back in the late 1940s, had been intended to weaken support for the "bourgeois parties", notably the <a href="Christian%20Democratic%20Union%20%28East%20Germany%29">CDU</a> which back then had presented a serious challenge to the one party structure favoured by <a href="Socialist%20Unity%20Party%20of%20Germany">the authorities</a>. In 1990, however, it was the <a href="Christian%20Democratic%20Union%20%28East%20Germany%29">CDU</a> that staged an electoral come back, and after briefly attempting to carve out a niche championing ecological causes, the DBD merged into the CDU at around the same time the East Germany <a href="German%20reunification">merged into</a> what many saw as an expandeded version of <a href="West%20Germany">West Germany</a>. Hans Rietz, by now an "elder statesman" of the DBD, stood out in opposition to the party merger: between 1990 and his death in 1996 he was not a member of any political party.
